playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: What are the APIErrors that are safe to retry? I'd rather we be explicit with the errors we allow than try and guess at the errors that will fail the download.

The API Errors that can be retried may show similar symptoms (e.g. 'no such host' for the case of a static configuration error or where the host may not be reachable, i.e. DNS error).  Update to exit on error in this script; the playbook will attempt to perform the retry and limit the overall attempts.
This can be rewritten as a tuple or just 'except Exception' as we aren't doing anything different for the subclasses.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Operationally this is not really a valid action. I think I've only seen one or two UEFI systems in the last five years which didn't support the UEFI SNP standard and even then the ipxe.efi binary didn't have the network drivers for them to work anyway.

Actually the main aim of this change is not let users switch back to ipxe*.efi in master but we can introduce this parameter to stable branches later so that users can switch from ipxe.efi to ipxe-snponly.efi.

Maybe we can discuss later whether we want to deprecate current capability to use ipxe.efi, but IMO leaving that option does not harm so much.

roles/check_uc_hostname/defaults/main.ym.message:
So what happen if the user decide to do have all its templates in:

 ~/ffu/

and adjust all the commands support this prefix directory ?

I think we should be more tolerant about user customization.

We have IMHO two ways to tackle this:
 1. look at what is defined in undercloud.conf
 2. look directly at the heat stack output.


1. is based on that parameter from the documentation: "container_images_file"[1][2]. The file that points to it will have the image definition. So the value of that parameter would be a better estimate of the user intend.

2. Now if the user is really savvy, ultimately the constraint defined in the documentation for the overcloud is:

parameter_defaults:
  DockerInsecureRegistryAddress:
  - undercloud.ctlplane.localdomain:8787
  - 192.168.24.1:8787

and somebody can defined this in *any* yaml file loaded during the ffwd prepare step.

This lead to the only robust way to check the value of this parameter for the overcloud:

(undercloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ openstack --os-cloud undercloud stack environment show qe-Cloud-0 --format json| jq '.parameter_defaults.DockerInsecureRegistryAddress'
[
  "undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787"
]

This can only be done after the ffwd prepare step though.


[1] see https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/16.1/html-single/framework_for_upgrades_13_to_16.1/index#updating-the-undercloud-conf-file-upgrading-undercloud
[2] note that in the undercloud.conf we also have container_insecure_registries should we test this as well ?

cinder/api/__init__.py.message: if v1 and v2 are gone, why do we even need a config option for enable_v3_api ?

Although enable_v2_api was deprecated a while back, it never occurred to us to also deprecate enable_v3_api (it's deprecated in cinder/common/config.py in this patch).  So technically, we can't remove it this cycle because cinder asserts the 'assert:follows-standard-deprecation' tag.

On the other hand, it seems dumb to keep it.  We discussed this at the midcycle [0] and decided to get some more info and if it's ok to remove it, do it in a follow-up patch.

[0] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CinderXenaMidCycleSummary#what_about_the_enable_v3_api_option.3F

cinder/common/config.py.message:
We should probably use "19.0.0" here instead of the codename.

    https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config/src/commit/1a7bd66a7179ca374e996e76f346def33787a21f/oslo_config/cfg.py#L454

We currently have it both ways in the cinder code.  Since oslo_config simply expects a string, I prefer using the release name since the deprecation period is tied more closely to development cycles than version numbers:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/assert_follows-standard-deprecation.html

Also, I think it's easier to spot these in the code and realize they should be removed when the release name is used.  But the other thing is that this option is still under discussion (one proposal is to simply remove it without deprecation because it doesn't do anything useful in Xena), so I'd prefer to hold off on this for a followup:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CinderXenaMidCycleSummary#what_about_the_enable_v3_api_option.3F

2021-07-28T11:56:58.290 controller-0 systemd-modules-load[1437]: err Failed to find module 'mlx4_en'
"""

Ok. mlx4 and mlx4_en have actually been deprecated, at least according to my tests, because the configure script no longer supports the --with-mlx4-mod... arguments:

  
"""
+ ./configure --build-dummy-mods --prefix=/usr --kernel-version 5.10.30-200.12.tis.el7.x86_64 --kernel-sources /usr/src/kernels/5.10.30-200.12.tis.el7.x86_64 --modules-dir /lib/modules/5.10.30-200.12.tis.el7.x86_64/extra/mlnx-ofa
_kernel --with-core-mod --with-user_mad-mod --with-user_access-mod --with-addr_trans-mod --with-mlx4-mod --with-mlx4_en-mod --with-mlx5-mod --with-mlxfw-mod --with-ipoib-mod -j72
Unsupported or unused parameter: --with-mlx4-mod
Unsupported or unused parameter: --with-mlx4_en-mod
"""

Given this, we should remove mlx4_ib, mlx4_core and mlx4_en from kernel-modules/mlnx-ofa_kernel/files/modules-load.conf in this repository.

    a required extra-specification until API version 2.24. When updating extra-specs
    of a share type, there's no need to provide required extra specifications
    unless they need to be updated.
    Some examples of extra-specifications include:
    ``replication_type``,
    ``snapshot_support``,
    ``mount_snapshot_support``,
    ``revert_to_snapshot_support``,
    ``create_from_snapshot_support``
  in: body
  required: true
  type: object

/COMMIT_MSG.message: So can we merge it now or should we wait for new neutron-lib release which will include [1]?

We can merge it now.

The n-lib patch if to sanitize the user input. That means, for example, if we merge this patch (without the n-lib one), the user will need to introduce manually a sanitized MAC address.

For example, this command won't return anything:
  openstack port list --mac-address 1:2:3:4:5:6

but this one will:
  openstack port list --mac-address 01:02:03:04:05:06

despite being the same MAC address.


If we need to set an order, this must be the first patch to be merged and then the n-lib one (bump the n-lib version). The optimal way is to do both, that's why I'll bump the n-lib version in this patch, waiting for a new n-lib release.

About the formula, inspiration is taken from https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/facter/os_workers.rb. May be we should make the formula for calculation changeable based on values.yaml? Your suggestion will be appreciate.

I'd go with just worker per pod and if it is required the pods can be scaled. I think managing manage workers this way fits better to a non Kubernetes environment.

Moreover, nproc inside a pod reports number of processors on the host. On a typical production system with 80 processors makes it 20 workers per pod as default. That might just be too high.

About the nproc part, thank you for pointing it out. But in default settings in values.yaml, right now there is no resources quota configured in default and here if we set the values in metadata_workers and osapi_compute_workers to Null, by default the workers count will be set to the number of processors which is not good options for machine like one having large number of cpu but less memory. So we thought maybe we can use some kind of formula to calculate the workers process. Scaling is the good options but increasing the worker count based on the machine type using some kind of formula might help while deploying in different environment with similar values file.

Sorry for the typos...

I'd go with just one worker per pod and if it is required the pods can be scaled. I think managing workers this way fits better to a non Kubernetes environment.

Moreover, nproc inside a pod reports number of processors on the host. On a typical production system with 80 processors makes it 20 workers per pod as default. That might just be too high.
Going by nproc, it also ignores any CPU resource limits sets on the pod.

I find myself agreeing with Reddy on this, and to sum up my concerns:
- we are introducing a "new" value here to a Nova config parameter that is not in their documentation (integers or null), so this may add confusion to some people.
- the formula chosen to calculate the number of workers process per pod is not easy to understand, and not easy to change (not configurable)
- and the concept of workers is really not needed in a containerized env, where anyone can easily control the resources (CPU/RAM/etc) on a pod to optimize it for 1 worker, and to scale it as needed (with proper affinity rules preferably)

If the issue is we are not optimizing the pod resources, let's update the limit to make it so, then we can just stick with the simple approach of scaling up and down as needed, instead of relying on some formula that is dependent on resource allocation.

files/glance_simplestreams_sync.py.message: Just curious, but is there a particular reason why `setup_file_logging` no longer returns the logger and you fetch it this way ? From my understanding, it should be the same object.
Ah, figured it was something related to tests. Thanks for the explanation. Looks good to me 😊

Line 66 in the old code

```
log = setup_logging()
```

used to introduce an import-time side effect: so when unit tests were executed and tried to import `glance_simplestreams_sync.py`, the code in `setup_logging` tried to do some things on a local file system to set up the file logger.

So I changed the behavior so that on import a module-level variable is set to the root logger without any additional handlers being added: if the module name happens to be '__main__' (e.g. in case of an invocation via the cron job), we would also set up logging to a file.

"naming things" is one of the hard things in software development, and I think this is a misleading name, for the following reasons:

 * It doesn't load a tree.  It actually loads a flat list of dictionaries.
 * It doesn't return a tree.  It returns a map of id -> the node of that id, which is half of a Schwartzian transform on the list of dicts by 'id'.

So the weird thing about this entire recursion is that at each level we do two things:
- we populate a "global" list called "descendants"
- we return that global list.

This doesn't look like recursions I have seen before. Usually a recursion looks something like this:

```
def recursive_func(parent):
    if stop_condition:
        return something
    return aggregation of current level and recursive_func(parent.children)
```

Do you see what I mean? There is no global list that gets populated at each level.

Now true, I have also seen recursions written with a global collection and no return value, then it looks like:

```
result = []
def recursive_func(parent):
    if stop_condition:
        return
    result.append(something from current level)
    recursive_func(parent.children)
```

But in your recursion, you're mixing both patterns: the one based on aggregating returned values and the one where we populate a global collection.

Now based on the example you have given in the docstring, I don't think this is needed. I think you can pick one of both patterns. What do you think?

I think if you do just "return" on line 645 and transform line 647 in

```
get_descendant(parent, [parent["id"]])
return descendants
```

then you get the same final results and it then follows pattern number 2 (the one populating a global collection). What do you think?
Yes, you are right. I mixed both patterns and I will use the second one as you suggested, because I don't see any simple solution how the aggregate returns from recursion.

Okay, I *think* I've worked out what is going on here, but please correct me if I'm wrong.

 * the output of ceph ... osd tree is a attribute-value list which represents multiple trees, with roots of type "root".
 * We'll assume that a tree can have leaf nodes that are in other trees.
 * The return value is a flattened list of host nodes, with attributes from the other linked nodes (via leaf nodes (children)).
 * This is essentially a de-normalised self joined table as a spreadsheet, but then indexed by the "host" node "id" as "identifier", and returned as [CrushLocation()]
 * Assumption is that the tree is a DAG (i.e. no cycles)

If this is true, then I would approach this problem in two steps:

1. flatten the tree by root node into a list of dictionaries (special case for host to keeps its id as 'identifier'.
2. map the dictionaries into CrushLocation() list.

Flatten is essentially:


    def flatten(node, node_lookup_map):
        attribute_dict = {node['type']: node['name']}
        if node['type'] == 'host':
            attribute_dict['identifier'] = node['id']
        descendant_attribute_dicts = [
            flatten(node_lookup_map[node_id])
            for node_id in node.get("children", [])]
        if descendant_attribute_dicts:
            return [attribute.copy().update(descendant_attribute_dict)
                    for descendant_attribute_dict in descendant_attribute_dicts]
        else:
            return [attribute]         

    def flatten_roots(nodes):
        let lookup_map = {node['id']: node for node in nodes}
        root_attributes_dicts = [flatten(node, lookup_map)
                                 for node in nodes
                                 if node['type'] == 'root']
        # get a flattened list of roots.
        return itertools.chain(*root_attributes_dicts)

    # finally for the (misnamed?) get_osd_tree

    def get_osd_tree(service):
        # do the stuff to get the nodes.
        return [CrushLocation(**host) for host in flatten_roots(nodes)]

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
How can these ever be verified when they come from RPC?

I'm sure nobody else agrees, but MHO is that this is less desirable than a docstring which provides the same amount of hint-age AFAICT.

> > I'm sure nobody else agrees, but MHO is that this is less
 > desirable
 > > than a docstring which provides the same amount of hint-age
 > AFAICT.
 > 
 > One doesn't preclude the other. Docstrings make sense to describe
 > the significance or use of the parameter, while annotations are
 > great to describe, in a structured, machine readable format, the
 > expected type. I have used these patches to improve upon docstrings
 > too in the past, but I clearly haven't been consistent about it.
 > Happy to rework this to add them here.

Done

> How can these ever be verified when they come from RPC?

They can't, and we're going to have to trust out RPC interfaces up to this point. From here on down though, it does propagate (or will, once I find a chunk of time to get type hints working for 'nova.objects' and o.vo as a whole). For example, consider:

  def foo(var):
      bar(var)

  def bar(wow: str):
      baz(wow)

  def baz(woo: int):
      print(woo)

Running this through mypy will yield the following:

  $ mypy test.py
  test.py:6: error: Argument 1 to "baz" has incompatible type "str"; expected "int"                                                                                                                                  
  Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)

 > I'm sure nobody else agrees, but MHO is that this is less desirable
 > than a docstring which provides the same amount of hint-age AFAICT.

One doesn't preclude the other. Docstrings make sense to describe the significance or use of the parameter, while annotations are great to describe, in a structured, machine readable format, the expected type. I have used these patches to improve upon docstrings too in the past, but I clearly haven't been consistent about it. Happy to rework this to add them here.

neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py.message: as commented in [1], those fields are not part of the port SQL query

> The queries you have reported in both links are the same, there is no difference. Those parameters are already loaded in another query. With this patch you are lazy loading them in another DB transaction, if needed.

Not sure I understand which another transaction you mean, can you please clarify?
I see 1 read transaction and it includes 1 query for ports table and 7 subqueries (http://paste.openstack.org/show/805749/). After the patch it's same query for ports table and only 4 subqueries (http://paste.openstack.org/show/805748/). My tests showed speedup in both list and show operations because of eliminating those 3 subqueries.

> 
> My reason to give a -1 to this patch is that if we are going to change both in show and list commands the port OVO model (because this is what we are doing), instead of doing that dynamically, we can do it statically changing the relationship of those fields (port_forwardings, binding_levels, distributed_port_binding).

The reason of doing it dynamically for List and Show is that for other operations (like port update/bind) those fields could be more effective to be loaded in current (subquery) mode. If do it statically we will likely slowdown those operations, won't we?

> 
> Just an example, for those parameters we already changed the port OVO view model [1]. The loading method was changed from "joined" to "subquery". We can change it again to "select" (same as lazyloading [2]).
> 
> I've tested that and I see a little speed improvement, both listing and showing a port, when changing the relationship of those field to select:
> - list (250 ports): 1.80secs to 1.65secs
> - show: 0.105secs to 0.090secs
> 
> Of course that will also depend on the DB backend but I think that could be interesting to propose this patch.
> 
> [1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/408143
> [2]https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/loading_relationships.html

> Disregard my first comment, once I published it I saw what you said.
> 
> When a port is updated, "get_port" is called too. For example, when you are binding it to a VM. So that change will affect to all port operations too. The effect of changing the relationship statically or dynamically will be the same (and I prefer to have it defined in the DB models).

right, but still there are many places where plugin.get_port() is not used - like ml2.db.get_port() (+ other funcs in ml2.db) used by ml2 plugin. Static change will affect it.

> 
> So I'll remove my -1 and I'll ask other reviewers to check it. As I said, I not against this change but changing the DB models statically.

That's correct, port SQL query is the same, but the number of subqueries is lower, even for single port subqueries for port_forwardings, binding_levels and distributed_port_binding are done when port is fetched from DB. I'll put paste links from OSProfiler shortly

Before patch: http://paste.openstack.org/show/805749/
With patch: http://paste.openstack.org/show/805748/

Disregard my first comment, once I published it I saw what you said.

When a port is updated, "get_port" is called too. For example, when you are binding it to a VM. So that change will affect to all port operations too. The effect of changing the relationship statically or dynamically will be the same (and I prefer to have it defined in the DB models).

So I'll remove my -1 and I'll ask other reviewers to check it. As I said, I not against this change but changing the DB models statically.

The queries you have reported in both links are the same, there is no difference. Those parameters are already loaded in another query. With this patch you are lazy loading them in another DB transaction, if needed.

My reason to give a -1 to this patch is that if we are going to change both in show and list commands the port OVO model (because this is what we are doing), instead of doing that dynamically, we can do it statically changing the relationship of those fields (port_forwardings, binding_levels, distributed_port_binding).

Just an example, for those parameters we already changed the port OVO view model [1]. The loading method was changed from "joined" to "subquery". We can change it again to "select" (same as lazyloading [2]).

I've tested that and I see a little speed improvement, both listing and showing a port, when changing the relationship of those field to select:
- list (250 ports): 1.80secs to 1.65secs
- show: 0.105secs to 0.090secs

Of course that will also depend on the DB backend but I think that could be interesting to propose this patch.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/408143
[2]https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/loading_relationships.html

* Connections are a dict instead of a list (this matches the spec).
* ssh_key -> sshkey -- that matches the name of the attribute we use in zuul.conf, so is a little more intuitive, and behaves well with the next change:
* The secrets for connections are actually treated as shadow dictionaries for the connections.  So rather than spelling out each of the secrets and keys for each attribute like:

  github:
    app_key:
      secretName: githubSecrets
      key: app_key
    webhook_token:
      secretName: githubSecrets
      key: webhook_token

We can:

  github:
    secretName: githubSecrets

  And the operator will just dict-merge all the key/values in githubSecrets into the connection entry in zuul.conf.  Obviously this doesn't match the spec.  It seems like an improvement worth doing though.

zuul_operator/templates/zuul.yaml.message:
This probably needs to support setting environment as well. Both to interpolate zuul.conf from environment for secrets and for things like http_proxy variables.

Something like:

```
spec:
  scheduler:
    count: 1
    config:
      secretName: zuul-tenant-config
    env:
      - name: ZUUL_GITHUB_WEBHOOK_TOKEN
        valueFrom:
          secretKeyRef:
            name: zuul-github
            key: token
      
```

And maybe even move the configuration item to use a configmap instead of a secret?

Yes for http_proxy.  I don't think we'll be supporting interpolating zuul.conf though, since we don't actually let the user provide a zuul.conf.

The github webhook token is intended to be provided by a secret like:

  metadata: {name: github-secret}
  stringData:
    webhook_token: ...
    app_key: ...

Then in the Zuul spec:

  connections:
    github:
      driver: github
      server: github.example.com
      secretName: github-secret

That has two good characteristics: the secret data are in secrets, and we don't have to map each individual field through -- they just get automatically merged.

We should update the docs with an example of this.
Yep. mixed up zuul-config vs zuul-tentant-config so that makes sense.
We sometimes have long running (~10h) jobs which shouldn't be aborted so it would be good if this was configurable.

zuul_operator/zuul.py.message:
I'm not really sure why this is expected to be a secret and not a configmap.

Though from what I understand there's not really any difference between cm's and secrets either more than to signal that there's sensitive data in secrets or restrict who or what can read secrets vs cm's.

But since it's possible to interpolate variables from the environment for both nodepool.yaml and zuul.conf I wouldn't expect them to contain any sensitive data.

Indeed, the spec had this as a configmap.  Technically you can put secret info in nodepool.yaml since we allow openstack cloud config in there, but the preferred way is definitely clouds.yaml, so it should be okay to switch it to a configmap.  Let's do that in a followup.

The diskimages section could still potentially require secrets to be passed to elements with env-var which could in turn be interpolated from nodepools environment.
https://zuul-ci.org/docs/nodepool/configuration.html#attr-diskimages.env-vars

However it looks like nodepools environment interpolation is documented except for a releasenote.
https://zuul-ci.org/docs/nodepool/releasenotes.html?highlight=nodepool_#relnotes-3-14-0-new-features

[root@standalone ~]# podman exec -it <a-stopped-container> ls
Error: can only create exec sessions on running containers: container state improper
[root@standalone ~]# echo $?
255

My main concern is with the naming. What we want is to create a transparent intermediate bridge between the integration bridge and the VM tap interface.

Neutron will create a Neutron DB port and a logical swith port (LSP) in the OVN NB DB. The LSP will refer to the Neutron DB port using the "lsp.name" field.

Without this patch, when the port is plugged, OVN ML2 pluggin waits for the creation event filtering by name (Neutron ID). Because we want this bridge to be transparent to Neutron (with some exceptions, QoS for example), I would suggest to change this patch name to "vif.vif_name".

BTW, in the port.external_ids there should be a reference to the TAP port ID. That will be read by Neutron and used for example in QoS extension.

the patch will have

            external_ids = {
                'iface-id': iface_id, 'iface-status': 'active',
                'attached-mac': mac, 'vm-uuid': instance_id
            }

today that is the api contract that we have betwen nova/os-vif and neutron

the prot on the brin will have those feled set and that is the only thing that any neutron backed should be useing to identify the port.
the name of the ovs port is technialy not part of the api contract so ovns use of lsp.name is not valid withint that contract.

i am using vif.vif_name for the name of the tap interface that is added to the port bridge.
i cannot use that for the patch port as ovs uses that name to find thet tap device.

so it would be incorerct to use vif.vif_name for the patch port.
i could add a new field to the external_ids which contains the the vif.vif_name

            external_ids = {
                'iface-id': iface_id, 'iface-status': 'active',
                'attached-mac': mac, 'vm-uuid': instance_id,
                'port-ref': vif.vif_name
            }

then the qos edxtetion can use that to determin what port to apply the qos rules too.

Right, I see in [1] you are assigning the iface-id to the patch port needed for ovn-controller to make the link between LSP and OVS port.

I've tested this patch with nova one and it's working: before the VM starts, OVN detects the port with the iface-id and Neutron receives the port UP event, that triggers the processing of the (LSP, Neutron DB) port.

That will also work with the current QoS implementation: we don't assign the queues to a port but using a "match" to a logical flow. I need to test it but I think we don't need to change anything there.
